data.title: Mid-Unit Assessment
data.student_instructions: You will need tracing paper and a straightedge for this assessment.
data.teacher_instructions: Give this assessment after Lesson 10. Students will need access to tracing paper and a straightedge.

assessment_problems.narrative: Students who select choice A or choice C may struggle to understand a sequence of translations. Students who select choice B may have trouble visualizing a reflection over a line which is not drawn for them. Students who do not select choice D may incorrectly add the angle measures of the rotation or not consider the direction of the rotations.
assessment_problems.statement: Which sequence of transformations would not return a shape to its original position?

choices:
Translate 3 units up, then 3 units down

Reflect over line , then reflect over line again

Translate 1 unit to the right, then 4 units to the left, then 3 units to the right

Rotate counterclockwise around center , then rotate counterclockwise around

goals.title: Find the image of figures under rigid transformations in the coordinate plane.

addressing.title: 8.G.1
addressing.description: Verify experimentally the properties of rotations, reflections, and translations:

addressing.title: 8.G.A.1
addressing.description: Verify experimentally the properties of rotations, reflections, and translations:

assessment_problems.narrative: Students who select choice A may notice that a rotation takes some of the sides of to . Students who select choice B may notice that a translation will take 3 of the sides of to .  Students who select choice E may notice that a reflection across will take 7 of the sides of to .
assessment_problems.statement: Select all the pairs where Figure is the image of Figure after a reflection, rotation, or translation.

choices:
Pair A

Pair B

Pair C

Pair D

Pair E

Pair F

addressing.title: 8.G.1.a
addressing.description: Lines are taken to lines, and line segments to line segments of the same length.

addressing.title: 8.G.1.b
addressing.description: Angles are taken to angles of the same measure.

addressing.title: 8.G.A.1.a
addressing.description: Lines are taken to lines, and line segments to line segments of the same length.

addressing.title: 8.G.A.1.b
addressing.description: Angles are taken to angles of the same measure.

assessment_problems.narrative: Students who select choice C identify parts of the figure that are not corresponding parts as having the same length. Students who select choice E may identify that the angles are the same measure but do not recall that vertical angles share a vertex.
assessment_problems.statement:
Line segment is the image of after a rotation around point .

Select all of the true statements about the figure.

assessment_problems.narrative: Students are presented with a shape and an image that is a translation, rotation, or reflection of the given shape. Students then identify the translation, rotation, or reflection. For this task, the shapes are on a grid.
assessment_problems.statement:
Here are three pairs of figures:

  1. Which transformation takes Figure A to Figure B in Pair 1:
    a translation, rotation, or reflection?
  2. Which transformation takes Figure A to Figure B in Pair 2:
    a translation, rotation, or reflection?
  3. Which transformation takes Figure A to Figure B in Pair 3:
    a translation, rotation, or reflection?

goals.title: Identify image of a shape under translation, rotation, and reflection.

addressing.title: 8.G.1
addressing.description: Verify experimentally the properties of rotations, reflections, and translations:

addressing.title: 8.G.A.1
addressing.description: Verify experimentally the properties of rotations, reflections, and translations:

assessment_problems.narrative: Segment lengths and angle measures are preserved by translations, reflections, and rotations. If two shapes do not have the same side lengths or angles, then one of them cannot be obtained from the other by a rigid transformation.
assessment_problems.statement:
1. Explain why Figure B is not the image of Figure A after a rotation using center .

  2. Explain why Figure B is not the image of Figure A after a rreflection using line .

problem_response.solution:
1. The shortest side of Figure A is longer than the shortest side of Figure B. Since rotations do not change lengths, Figure B is not a rotation of Figure A.
  2. The angles in Figure B do not match the corresponding angles in Figure A. Some of the angles in Figure A look like right angles while some corresponding angles in Figure B are definitely not right angles.

Minimal Tier 1 response:

  • Work is complete and correct.
  • Sample:
  1. The side lengths of the figures aren’t the same.
  2. The angle measures of the figures aren’t the same.

Tier 2 response:

  • Work shows general conceptual understanding and mastery, with some errors.
  • Sample errors: Generic statement about shape, such as “The two figures have different shapes”; stating that the second shape has different side lengths without being specific (only one of the side lengths is visibly different); stating that the first shape has different angle measures without being specific.

Tier 3 response:

  • Significant errors in work demonstrate lack of conceptual understanding or mastery.
  • Sample errors: Omitted explanations; stating that Figure B is the image of Figure A.

goals.title: Know that rigid transformations preserve side lengths and angles.

addressing.title: 8.G.1.a
addressing.description: Lines are taken to lines, and line segments to line segments of the same length.

addressing.title: 8.G.1.b
addressing.description: Angles are taken to angles of the same measure.

addressing.title: 8.G.A.1.a
addressing.description: Lines are taken to lines, and line segments to line segments of the same length.

addressing.title: 8.G.A.1.b
addressing.description: Angles are taken to angles of the same measure.

assessment_problems.narrative: In order to apply rigid transformations to polygons and other shapes, students practice applying them to single points. Lines of reflection are restricted to the - and -axes, while rotations are about the origin and are multiples of .
assessment_problems.statement:
Point is located at coordinates .

What are the coordinates of each point?

  1. Point is the image of after a rotation of using as center.
  2. Point  is the image of after a translation 2 units to the right, then a reflection using the -axis.
  3. Point  is the image of after a reflection using the -axis, then a translation 2 units to the right.

addressing.title: 8.G.3
addressing.description: Describe the effect of dilations, translations, rotations, and reflections on two-dimensional figures using coordinates.

addressing.title: 8.G.A.3
addressing.description: Describe the effect of dilations, translations, rotations, and reflections on two-dimensional figures using coordinates.

assessment_problems.narrative: A figure is given on a grid. Students apply a rigid transformation to the shape, drawing the final result. Students also identify and label corresponding parts in an image given information on the original figure.
assessment_problems.statement:
1. Draw the image of this figure under a  clockwise rotation using center .

  2. The figure on the left is reflected using line  to form the image on the right. Use the information in the original figure to label the corresponding side lengths and angle measures of the image.

problem_response.solution:
2.  

Minimal Tier 1 response:

  • Work is complete and correct, with complete explanation or justification.
  • Sample:
  1. See diagram. The image is drawn correctly, with all vertices in correct locations, and all edges drawn.
  2. See diagram 

Tier 2 response:

  • Work shows good conceptual understanding and mastery, with either minor errors or correct work with insufficient explanation or justification.
  • Sample errors: One point in the image for part a is incorrectly located; the image in part a is drawn with a counterclockwise rotation; one angle or length in part b is incorrect.

Tier 3 response:

  • Work shows a developing but incomplete conceptual understanding, with significant errors.
  • Sample errors: More than one point in part a is incorrectly located; the image in part a is drawn with a rotation or other incorrect angle of rotation; more than one angle or length in part b is incorrect (this includes the case where all angles and lengths have been drawn in as if the image were a rotation or if it were the original shape without reflection).

Tier 4 response:

  • Work includes major errors or omissions that demonstrate a lack of conceptual understanding and mastery.
  • Sample errors: major errors or omissions in one problem part along with errors in the other; two or more error types from Tier 3 response

goals.title: Given a figure and a translation, rotation, or reflection, draw the image of the figure under the transformation.
